title: Was there a single incident that triggered the chain of events that brought down communism in East Europe? - Quora

response.answer_text: No single good answer, I think. Real world is way too complex, to search for “single incidents”. School programs, in pretty much all fields, are notorious for presenting the knowledge “as if it were simple and easy to understand”. This is a huge con we play on kids for centuries - we make them believe, in school, that everything can be easily explained, that everything is simple. Maybe one unintended result of that (otherwise noble) attempt to “make the world understandable by teaching in school” are various religious sects and loony political movements. People are taught in school that things are simple. So, later in life, people demand, and get, simple answers for everything. Say, “it is all them Jews”. Worked for the Germans, did it not? There is a reason, why pretty much any profession has a long “apprenticeship” period. When people, out of school, learn that it is really not all that simple. One has to start with the “communism in East Europe was not that simple phenomenon”. You cannot investigate “how did it end”, unless you understand how it started, and how did it last. The simple version has it “it was a Soviet occupation”. OK, if one needs a one liner, this would be it, correct. Hence, the simple answer would be “once Gorbachev decided and announced that the Soviet army will switch from an occupational role to a consensual ally role, communism in East Block was a goner”. Is the above true? Yes. Is it true deeply, comprehensively enough, to be useful? Frankly, I do not know. We miss a lot with those one-liners. We miss a lot of understanding. That lack of understanding bites us later, I think.

I’m going to say “yes”, but with a big catch. That big catch is that there really isn’t a way of establishing what that single event was. An economic historian would point to an economic cause, a political historian to a political cause, a military historian to a military one (perhaps Afghanistan?), and a historian from or of one of the countries involved may well focus on local issues there and find similarities across the region. It’s the same with pretty much any other major event in history. You could argue that the First World War started due to Gavrilo Princip shooting Franz Ferdinand, but the reality is that something would have started it if Princip had been at home in bed with the flu, or someone had joggled his arm at the critical moment. In relation to the collapse of the Soviet Union, you could say (and you wouldn’t be wrong) that the stagnation of the late-Brezhnev-era USSR set things in motion which couldn’t be stopped by the time Gorbachev took over. Alternatively, you could say that it was all Gorbachev. Or you could point to someone like Lech Wałesa. I know someone who would argue quite cogently that “the single event” which triggered the collapse of the USSR was the establishment of the USSR, if you want to go backwards in time.

No. It is an absurd and impossible proposition that communism ever existed in Eastern Europe, or anywhere else, for that matter. It is also an ahistorical proposition that a single event precipitated the collapse of the Soviet Union’s client states. Eastern Europe The Collapse Of The Kremlin’s Empire A socialist analysis of the events in Eastern Europe “What justification is there, then, for terming the upheaval in Russia a socialist revolution? None whatever beyond the fact that the leaders of the November movement claim to be Marxian socialists”. Quoted from an article entitled “The Revolution in Russia – Where it Fails” in the Socialist Standard, August 1918. Introduction The events in Eastern Europe in the winter of 1989/90 shattered many of the illusions of workers who had imagined that the political and economic system that existed in those countries had something to do with socialism.  The Myth of Soviet “Socialism” An analysis from Russia makes many of the points we do. On all sides we hear it said that “after 1917 a Marxist utopia was realised in our country,” that we had a “communist regime” or “socialist state,” that “we were building socialism and communism,” and so on. This makes it essential for us to grasp the true essence of Marxism, to understand what socialism and communism are.  Socialism/communism, it means the same in the classical Marxian, pre-Leninist sense, will be an advanced , post-capitalist society, run by us all, locally, regionally, globally, in administration over resources and not a government over people. It will be a market -free, money -free, production for use (not for sale), free access (not rationed access) commonly owned,(not private, corporate or state owned) revolutionary permanent break with the present capitalist one. It has never existed anywhere. It is not a ‘reformist’ nor a ‘statist’ version of capitalism which retains wage slavery in any form. It will be the mature, politically conscious task of the immense majority to make it happen and not the minority vanguardist led actions of pseudo-revolutionaries. “The organising tenet will be from each according to their abilities, to each according to their needs.”

20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union - Wikipedia. THE TWENTIETH CPSU CONGRESS: THE ANTI-STALIN BOMBSHELL  The 20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union was held during the period 14–25 February 1956. It is known especially for First Secretary Nikita Khrushchev's "Secret Speech", which denounced the personality cult and dictatorship of Joseph Stalin.  It was a most traumatizing experience for thousands upon thousands of militants educated in the cult of Stalin to learn from world communism’s most authoritative voice that “he who had been the leader of progressive humanity, the inspiration of the world, the father of the Soviet people, the master of science and learning, the supreme military genius, and altogether the greatest genius in history was in reality a paranoiac torturer, a mass murderer, and a military ignoramus who had brought the Soviet state to the verge of disaster.  The self-confidence in many countries of the communist ruling class was shattered at the moment of the Twentieth CPSU Congress. The old idols and sacred values were torn apart, and the need for an autonomous domestic way to socialism was reasserted. The meaning of the resurgence was unequivocal: It signified a resolute break with the Stalinist conception of the leading role of the party apparatus. To disseminate their unorthodox views, intellectuals decided to go into the factories and talk to the industrial workers. The political and intellectual life was thus increasingly polarized between the Stalinist nostalgia and the partisans of change. The shock created by Khrushchev’s de-Stalinization campaigns affected all East European countries. The disarray among local elites resulted in the loosening of party controls and the emergence of emancipating movements from below, especially in Poland and Hungary. Once the Stalinist anti-Tito charges were exposed as insane fabrications, the national communist temptation became rampant in the region. The demolition of Stalin’s myth and Khrushchev’s calls for a creative approach to revolutionary doctrine emboldened unorthodox thinkers to question the foundations of the existing order.   The Soviet Union tried to save as much as possible of its ideological myths, but the wave of liberalization swept irresistibly through the satellite countries. The most dynamic examples in discovering a new sense of autonomy and in attempts to relinquish the frozen Stalinist carcass turned out to be Hungary and Poland. Profound effects from the Soviet Congress also were felt in all the other bloc countries, where the party intelligentsia became increasingly radicalized and critical of the past abuses.

It's not an incident rather, but a process that must have happened. Socialism is an unprofitable, inefficient and ineffective system. Therefore, communism had to collapse. Of course, we can observe that certain events may have accelerated the collapse of the Soviet dictatorship. One of them was Mikhail Gorbachev's assumption of the function of secretary general. An equally important event (in my opinion) was the failure of the Chernobyl plant, which put a heavy burden on the Soviet Union. Also, attention should be paid to Romania and the revolution that took place there. I think this event showed many communist dignitaries how they could end up if they didn't let go.

You might point to the announcement by Günter Schabowski in East Germany that the Berlin Wall would no longer be defended that triggered the extraordinary events of November 1989 and the rapid collapse of both the wall, East Germany and the entire Soviet area But that event whilst trigger that unleashed a tidal wave of change was itself preceeded by many and varied tensions pre-dating that I would compare Günter Schabowski words to the assigntion of Archduke Ferdinand in its effect of releasing pre-existing tensions rather than it being a cause itself
